author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Jazz Guitar
description: The instrument hasn’t always been a central player in jazz, but the best guitarists have taken up the challenge of finding their own way. Fourteen musicians and writers share their favorites.
content: If you go back far enough, it gets hard to tell genres apart. Just under a century ago, it wasn’t totally clear yet what was jazz and what was blues, or what was becoming R&B and what would soon turn into rock ’n’ roll. And the guitar was near the center of them all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Ken Bensinger
title: As Elon Musk Embraces Far Right, Some of Its Top Figures Reject Him
description: Mr. Musk has fallen out with prominent right-wing Americans who say they are worried that their agenda may be sidelined in favor of his own — and that he is willing to silence them on X.
content: When Laura Loomer, a far-right activist, regained control of her Twitter account in late 2022, she knew whom to praise for her reinstatement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Dignified Rituals Before the ‘Hot Mess’ in Washington
description: Jimmy Carter’s funeral is giving the nation an uncanny week of routine on the eve of political upheaval.
content: Americans know what to do when a president dies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Army Doctor Pleads Guilty to Sexually Assaulting Dozens of Patients
description: The doctor, Maj. Michael Stockin, was accused of sexual misconduct by 41 male patients in one of the largest such cases in military history.
content: An Army doctor pleaded guilty in a military court on Tuesday to sexually assaulting dozens of his patients, bringing one of the military’s largest sex abuse cases closer to resolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: Wildfires Can Harm Your Health, Even if You’re Far Away, Experts Say
description: Some studies have indicated that young children, especially those under the age of 4, are at particular risk because their lungs are still developing.
content: The air quality deteriorated on Tuesday evening in Pacific Palisades, as fast-moving fires raged in Southern California, creating conditions considered risky for children, older adults and people with lung or heart diseases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: A Dangerously Dry Southern California Was Ready to Burn
description: Parched vegetation combined with strong Santa Ana winds and low relative humidity levels led to the devastating wildfires in Los Angeles County.
content: Tens of thousands of people were ordered to flee their homes across Los Angeles County on Tuesday as multiple out-of-control wildfires, fueled by the strongest Santa Ana wind event in over a decade, threatened communities including Pacific Palisades and Altadena.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Panama Is Unsettled by Trump’s Threat to Seize Canal
description: Few took the president-elect’s combative comments at face value, but they still sent a shudder through a country that the United States has invaded before.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s suggestion on Tuesday that the United States might reclaim the Panama Canal — potentially by force — unsettled Panamanians, who used to live with the presence of the U.S. military in the canal zone and were invaded by American forces once before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Adam Liptak
title: Trump Asks Supreme Court to Halt His Sentencing in N.Y. Criminal Case
description: Prosecutors have been ordered to respond to the president-elect’s request by Thursday morning, suggesting the court could rule before Friday’s scheduled sentencing.
content: Days away from his criminal sentencing in New York, President-elect Donald J. Trump is seeking a late-stage rescue from the U.S. Supreme Court that would shut down the case before he returns to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Obamacare Enrollment Hits Record Ahead of Trump’s Return
description: Almost 24 million Americans have signed up for plans offered under the Affordable Care Act, driven by subsidies that are expiring and that Congress may not renew.
content: The number of Americans enrolled in the Affordable Care Act’s health insurance marketplaces has roughly doubled since President Biden took office, but White House officials warned Wednesday that the surge in Americans taking advantage of increased government health care subsidies could face risks as President-elect Donald J. Trump returns to office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italian Journalist Released by Iran
description: Cecilia Sala, 29, was detained last month while on a reporting trip. She had been held for 20 days and told her family that she was kept in isolation.
content: Cecilia Sala, an Italian journalist who was arrested last month in Iran while on a reporting trip, was released on Wednesday and is now back in Italy, putting an end to a detention that had gripped her country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Trump Wants Oil Drilling in Alaska. A Lease Sale There Just Flopped.
description: No companies bid for the chance to drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. It was the second auction in four years that failed to draw strong interest.
content: One of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s biggest “drill, baby, drill” initiatives suffered a significant setback on Wednesday as the Interior Department announced that a lease sale in Alaska’s Arctic National Wildlife Refuge ended without a single bidder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: How Bodyguards Are Keeping South Korea’s Leader From Detention
description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s security service stopped an effort to detain him on insurrection charges and has vowed to do so again. Its roots are in the era of military dictatorships.
content: South Korea’s Presidential Security Service, a​n agency​ assigned to protect the president, prides itself on being the “last bastion for a safe and stable state administration.” It is now at the heart of South Korea’s biggest political mess in decades, acting as a final line of defense to prevent criminal investigators from detaining President Yoon Suk Yeol on​ charges of insurrection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: At the Movies, the ‘Older Woman’ Is Growing Up
description: She has been called “cougar,” “Mrs. Robinson” and “your mom.” Now she’s the protagonist, and one of film and television’s most compelling characters.
content: The older woman has been very busy lately. By “older woman,” I am referring to the cinematic figure who is defined by her sexual and romantic relationships with younger men. Depending on your own age, you may know her as the “cougar,” the “Mrs. Robinson,” or the joke about “your mom.” Now she is the protagonist. And she has never had so many scene partners to choose from.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: President Biden Becomes a Great-Grandfather
description: Mr. Biden said his eldest granddaughter, Naomi, gave birth to a baby boy in California.
content: President Biden became a great-grandfather on Wednesday after his eldest granddaughter gave birth to a baby boy in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Poking Fun at Trump, Mexico’s President Suggests Renaming the U.S.
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico also said Donald Trump was ill-informed when he said Mexico was “essentially run by the cartels.”
content: Mexico’s president rejected several of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s assertions about her country and even joked that the United States should be called “Mexican America” after Mr. Trump said the Gulf of Mexico should be renamed the Gulf of America.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Each Cinematic Conquest Convinced Me You’d Call’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: We met at the employee Christmas party at a place where I didn’t work. Open bar. We traded lipstick colors and a kiss. Later, we went on a sprawling epic of a date: pingpong, Louisiana swamp at night (no flashlight), roller skating, gas station wine and ooey-gooey cake. I moved out of state and lost June’s number when my flip phone drowned in a mud puddle. We completely lost touch, but I never forgot her. Six years later, I moved back to New Orleans and walked into a bar. There June was. Turns out, she never forgot me either. — Amanda Casassa
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Fear on the Subway: Perception and Reality
description: The chance of being a crime victim in the subway is remote. But riders feel far more at risk than they do driving on New York’s streets and highways.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at the perceptions and the realities of crime in the subway. And, because it’s the first day of the state legislative session, we’ll look at the colonial-era lawyer who compiled a book of state laws when state government was brand-new.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: What to Know About the Santa Ana Winds
description: The winds are common in California in the colder months, but they can sometimes help spread dangerous wildfires.
content: A Santa Ana wind event is fueling wildfires in Los Angeles that have destroyed homes and forced the evacuation of thousands of people. Here’s what to know about the winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Power lines, involved in previous California fires, will be under scrutiny again.
description: It’s too early to know what started the fires burning in and around Los Angeles, but investigators will most likely examine whether power lines were involved.
content: It’s too early to know what started the fires burning in and around Los Angeles, but investigators will most likely examine whether power lines were involved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
title: U.S. Funding Dispute With World Anti-Doping Agency Boils Over
description: After the Biden administration withheld funding to the agency, saying it had lost confidence in its ability to police elite athletes, WADA removed the United States from its board.
content: The fallout from the disclosure that the World Anti-Doping Agency did not discipline a slew of Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned drug erupted on Wednesday after the Biden administration said it withheld major funding for the agency and the agency removed the American government’s representative from its board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Justice Dept. to Hold Off Releasing Report on Trump Documents Case
description: But in a court filing, the department indicated that it would release a separate report about Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election as soon as possible.
content: Federal prosecutors said on Wednesday that they planned to hold off on releasing a portion of a report by the special counsel, Jack Smith, detailing his investigation into President-elect Donald J. Trump’s refusal to give back a trove of classified documents he took from the White House after leaving office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: New Warnings About Alcohol Hit Restaurants at a Tricky Time
description: The surgeon general’s call to arms about the link between drinking and cancer could strike at a fiscal lifeline for restaurateurs facing falling sales.
content: The U.S. surgeon general’s new push to warn consumers about the link between drinking and cancer comes at a precarious time for restaurant owners trying to pencil out a profit that hinges on alcohol sales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: ‘The Embers Were Just Flying’: Two Friends’ Rush to Save a Family Home
description: After evacuating, Orly Israel and a friend went back to his family’s house to try to protect it. But the furious blaze was too much.
content: It seemed as if the sky was raining fire on Orly Israel’s home. With embers whipping through the air, trees blazing and alarms blaring, Mr. Israel raced through the yard, hosing down bushes in a desperate attempt to save the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Josh White Jr., Who Built on His Father’s Folk Legacy, Dies at 84
description: He began performing at 4 alongside his father, the celebrated singer and guitarist Josh White, and later carved out his own career.
content: Josh White Jr., who began his long career at age 4 performing alongside his father, the famed blues singer and guitarist Josh White, before carving out his own identity in the 1960s folk revival based in Greenwich Village, died on Dec. 28 at his home in Rochester, Mich., one day after announcing his retirement. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Eckholm
title: How to Cross the Government’s ‘Valley of Death’ and Fix How It Spends Billions on Stuff
description: The system has been criticized for being too prescriptive and ponderous. Now states and local governments are finding new ways to make the process work.
content: A very big ax may soon fall on the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: What Matters More for Longevity: Genes or Lifestyle?
description: It depends on what your goal is.
content: When Dr. Nir Barzilai met the 100-year-old Helen Reichert, she was smoking a cigarette. Dr. Barzilai, the director of the Institute for Aging Research at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, recalled Mrs. Reichert saying that doctors had repeatedly told her to quit. But those doctors had all died, Mrs. Reichert noted, and she hadn’t. Mrs. Reichert lived almost another decade before passing away in 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Where the Major Fires Are Burning in Southern California
description: Several significant blazes are burning in the Los Angeles area, destroying homes and forcing tens of thousands of people to evacuate. Here’s a look at the fires.
content: To look at a map of the Los Angeles region is to see enormous stretches under evacuation orders because of wildfires, from the Santa Monica and Malibu beach communities to suburban neighborhoods in Pasadena and parts of ranch country in the San Fernando Valley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.3 Million Homes in Florida, New York and Maryland
description: A Pueblo-style house in Miami, an 1890 townhouse in Hudson and a midcentury-modern-style home in North Bethesda.
content: This three-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bathroom house known as Casa Azul is in Spring Garden, a neighborhood less than 20 minutes from South Beach and bordered by the Miami River. A Metrorail station is a five-minute walk, and the University of Miami Health System hospital complex is a five-minute drive. The Wynwood Walls, a street art installation with surrounding shops, is a 10-minute drive, as is the Miami Design District.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m Speaking at a Friend’s Funeral. Can I Tell a Story that Could be Wrong?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the fallibility of memory.
content: I am going to tell a brief story about my friend at his funeral. The incident happened 65 years ago. The problem is that I am unsure whether the details of the story, as I remember them, are factual or just in my imagination. No one who was a witness at the time is still living. Should I make this story delightful and not worry about the facts, or make the story short, truthful and perhaps dull? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wildfires in Southern California
description: Plus, we explain why Facebook is getting rid of fact-checking.
content: Wildfires are raging out of control across parts of Los Angeles. A fierce windstorm is fanning embers, billowing dangerous smoke across the city and turning the sky an apocalyptic red.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Port Workers Could Strike Again if No Deal Is Reached on Automation
description: Cargo could stop flowing at East and Gulf Coast ports, which handle most imports, if a union and an employers’ group can’t agree on the use of machines that can operate without humans.
content: Ports on the East and Gulf Coasts could close next week if dockworkers and employers cannot overcome their big differences over the use of automated machines to move cargo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Biden Says He’s Considering Pre-emptive Pardons for Potential Trump Targets
description: The president hasn’t yet decided what he will do, he said, acknowledging that the makeup of Trump’s new administration could influence his decision.
content: President Biden said in a new interview published on Wednesday that he was considering pre-emptive pardons for people President-elect Donald J. Trump considered his political enemies, but he added that he had not yet decided what to do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Out-of-Control Fires Devastate Los Angeles Area
description: Also, no one bid for the chance to drill in Alaska’s wilderness. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Several major wildfires, fueled by fierce winds and dry vegetation, scorched Los Angeles all day long. More than 1,000 homes and businesses were reduced to ash. The fires have killed least two people and forced more than 100,000 others to evacuate. Many of my colleagues are on the ground there, reporting live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Donovan
title: Cook With Warmth and Hospitality. Cook With Vegetables.
description: Early lessons in vegetarianism informed a lifetime of cooking — and this hearty pozole verde.
content: In a pretty, bucolic North Georgia pasture, where old mine shafts lay hidden (but still accessible, as my crew of bored Gen X teenagers would discover) under the hills, lived a cow I once loved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Rate-Cut Decision Was Narrow, Fed Minutes Show
description: Stubborn inflation, and potential tariffs, make future rate cuts uncertain.
content: Federal Reserve officials cut interest rates as expected last month. But minutes from their December meeting suggest that the decision was a close call — and that there is no guarantee policymakers will lower rates again anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Matt Gaetz Floats a Run for Florida Governor in 2026
description: The former congressman was the focus of a House Ethics panel report accusing him of “regularly” paying for sex and using drugs, which helped doom his short-lived nomination for attorney general.
content: Former Representative Matt Gaetz, who withdrew as President-elect Donald J. Trump’s nominee for attorney general ahead of the release of a House Ethics panel report that accused him of “regularly” paying for sex and using drugs, said he was “starting to think about running for governor” next year in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: N.Y.C. Election Board Refused to Fire Leader Who Harassed Female Workers
description: The executive director of the New York City Board of Elections made inappropriate sexual and racial remarks toward two employees over a period of several months, a watchdog found.
content: The New York City Board of Elections refused to remove its executive director after a city investigation recommended in November that he be fired for sexually and racially harassing two employees, according to a report released by the city’s Department of Investigation on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dodai Stewart
title: He’s a Security Guard at the Met. Now His Work Is Showing There.
description: How the dream of a lifetime became reality for a sculptor from Egypt.
content: One day in the summer of 2023, Armia Khalil, a security guard at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, noticed a visitor wandering through a gallery, clearly looking for something specific.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner and Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: Los Angeles Battles Deadly Wildfires
description: Plus, how genetics factor into longevity.
content: Multiple out-of-control blazes in the Los Angeles area yesterday killed at least two people and seriously injured many others. The fires destroyed homes and businesses and blanketed highways in smoke. Officials warned of a dwindling water supply and said the worst was yet to come. Follow our live coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Carole Wilbourn, Who Put Cats on the Couch, Dies at 84
description: When cats bite or scratch, they’re trying to tell you something. Ms. Wilbourn, a cat therapist, was a pioneer in the art of listening to them.
content: Carole Wilbourn, a self-described cat therapist, who was known for her skill in decoding the emotional life of cats, as confounding as that would seem to be, died on Dec. 23 at her home in Manhattan. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Angwin
title: This Is What It Looks Like When Mark Zuckerberg Runs Out of Ideas
description: He has leveraged his political ambiguity to strengthen Meta, with consequences for the future of Silicon Valley and for the truth.
content: There is no shortage of speculation as to how much Elon Musk and his companies will benefit financially from his enthusiastic embrace of President-elect Donald Trump. Yet I believe that it is Mark Zuckerberg, Mr. Musk’s lower-key, more politically fluid tech-billionaire rival, who should be crowned Silicon Valley’s wiliest operator in the halls of Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Israeli Soldiers on Vacation Are Being Investigated for War Crimes in Gaza
description: The Israeli military will no longer identify its forces by name in the media, “fearing the arrest of soldiers abroad.”
content: An Israeli reservist left Brazil in a hurry this week after a Brazilian judge ordered an investigation into whether he committed war crimes in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: For Him, the Beer in Your Hand Is the End of the Story
description: Joshua M. Bernstein was writing about bars and nightlife when the craft brew wave started to rise.
content: Asked to name a few of his favorites places to stop in for a drink, Joshua M. Bernstein was caught off guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Carlos Prieto, Diana Nguyen, Michael Simon Johnson, Maria Byrne, Devon Taylor, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop and Alyssa Moxley
title: The End of Justin Trudeau’s Canada
description: A guide to the collapse of a prime minister who was once a progressive icon, and to the conservative populist who could replace him.
content: This week, Justin Trudeau said he would step down as prime minister of Canada — a stunning downfall for a man who was once seen as a global icon of progressive politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: Mourners Defy Subfreezing Temperatures to Honor Jimmy Carter at the Capitol
description: While cold weather and heightened security most likely dampened turnout, thousands of well-wishers still traipsed through the snow and ice to pay final tribute to the 39th president.
content: They came amid the ice and snow, bundled in parkas and long johns, expecting an hourslong wait in the subfreezing temperatures and whipping winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Jokes Its Way From Canada to the ‘Gulf of America’
description: “We have been so concerned about all the scary things that Trump’s going to do, we forgot he’s also going to do some really stupid things,” Desi Lydic said on “The Daily Show.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 578
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Jan. 9, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: Four Fraternity Members Charged After a Pledge Is Set on Fire
description: Prosecutors said that a skit last year left a San Diego State University student with third-degree burns over 16 percent of his body.
content: Four fraternity members at San Diego State University are facing felony charges after a pledge was set on fire during a skit at a party last year, leaving him hospitalized for weeks with third-degree burns, prosecutors said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: ‘Here We Go Again’: Trump’s Territorial Ambitions Rattle a Weary World
description: A distant era of global politics, when nations scrambled to grab territory, suddenly seems less distant.
content: When Donald J. Trump won a return to the White House, many countries thought they knew what to expect and how to prepare for what was coming.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 51st State? Canadians Say No Thanks.
description: Canadians react to Donald Trump’s proposal. Also: Trump on the Panama Canal and Greenland; Trump and TikTok; Meta and fact-checking; a messy home.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson and Kate Conger
title: Meet the Next Fact-Checker, Debunker and Moderator: You
description: Meta is joining X and YouTube in shifting moderation to users. Are you ready?
content: Meta would like to introduce its next fact-checker — the one who will spot falsehoods, pen convincing corrections and warn others about misleading content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla, Jesus Jiménez, Yan Zhuang and Kate Selig
title: What We Know About the Wildfires Raging in Southern California
description: The huge, fast-moving fires are stretching the region’s firefighting resources and have become the most destructive in the history of Los Angeles.
content: The most destructive wildfires in Los Angeles’s history have razed neighborhoods, forced desperate evacuations and threatened wealthy, iconic parts of the city — and they appear far from being contained as firefighters strain against fierce winds and dry conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Blames California’s Governor, and His Water Policy, for Wildfires
description: Donald J. Trump issued angry comments about Gov. Gavin Newsom, and President Biden was briefed in California by the state’s fire officials.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Wednesday blamed California’s Democratic governor for the failure to contain fires engulfing parts of the Los Angeles area, turning a still-evolving natural disaster into a political opportunity and accusing the state’s government of letting environmental policies run amok.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Why Does Trump Want the Panama Canal? Here’s What to Know.
description: Treaties ratified by the Senate in 1978 established permanent neutrality, but some Republicans regret that decision.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump on Tuesday refused to rule out using military force to retake the Panama Canal, which was returned by the U.S. to that country’s control decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: When There’s a Dearth of Good Information on Women’s Health, a Million Scams Bloom
description: Especially when fertility is involved.
content: In my mid-20s, a gynecologist diagnosed me with polycystic ovary syndrome, or PCOS, a common hormonal condition for which there is no standard test; only a constellation of symptoms can trigger a diagnosis. I was told I could have trouble getting pregnant and was given very little additional information, though internet research suggested I might be at greater risk for diabetes and cardiovascular problems later in life. I always knew I wanted children. I was devastated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Schools Close Across Los Angeles County as Wildfires Rage
description: At least 18 of the 80 school districts in the county announced that schools would be closed and urged parents to take precautions as at least four wildfires burned.
content: The wildfires burning in Southern California have prompted officials to close schools across Los Angeles County on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Jenny Gross
title: Ozempic, Lego Bricks and Hearing Aids: What Trump’s Greenland Plan Could Hit
description: Putting tariffs on Denmark unless it cedes the island of Greenland could hurt access to a few key products, including popular medicines.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump has threatened tariffs on many countries for many different reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Brother and Sister-in-Law No Longer Want to Put Me Up. I’m Hurt!
description: A reader feels stung by her brother and his wife’s cooling to an idea that they had once seemed open to: hosting her once a month when she commutes to a faraway office job.
content: For over a decade, my partner and I lived overseas. We have now moved back home to be closer to family. We chose a small city that’s near several relatives. My partner has found work, but there are fewer options here for me. I have an exciting prospect in a larger city that’s two and a half hours away. There is an expectation that I will go into the office once a week. My brother, his wife and their two young children live there. They have a large house. A while ago, we talked about my staying with them once a month if I got the job. They were enthusiastic about it, and I was excited to spend time with them. More recently, though, they said they don’t want me or anyone else as a regular houseguest. I don’t think anything has changed in our relationship. I feel hurt and rejected. What should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Study Links High Fluoride Exposure to Lower I.Q. in Children
description: The results of a new federal analysis were drawn from studies conducted in other countries, where drinking water contains more fluoride than in the United States.
content: Water fluoridation is widely seen as one of the great public health achievements of the 20th century, credited with substantially reducing tooth decay. But there has been growing controversy among scientists about whether fluoride may be linked to lower I.Q. scores in children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Healthy Eating Habits
description: How healthy is your diet? What can you do in 2025 to improve it?
content: It’s the start of the New Year, a time when many recommit to healthy habits. And perhaps no habit is more important than a healthy diet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Emily Baumgaertner, Robert Jimison, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Wildfires Roar Through L.A., and Trump Floats U.S. Expansion
description: Plus, the end of Facebook fact-checking.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Jenna Bush Hager: ‘Today’ Show Co-Host, Literary Tastemaker and Now, Publisher
description: Nearly six years after becoming a literary heavyweight with “Read with Jenna,” she’s starting her own publishing venture with Penguin Random House.
content: Jenna Bush Hager, who became one of the most influential figures in publishing when she launched a book club on the “Today” show nearly six years ago, said on Wednesday that she now plans to do more than just recommend books: She’s going to publish them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: SAG Award Nominations 2025: ‘Wicked’ Casts a Strong Spell
description: The box office hit landed five nods, while “The Last Showgirl” received unexpected recognition for stars Pamela Anderson and Jamie Lee Curtis.
content: “Wicked” led this year’s nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards, which were announced Wednesday morning. The announcement was supposed to take place live but the organization said that out of concern for the spreading wildfires in Los Angeles, the nominations would be relayed by news release instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: In Tibet, Survivors of Strong Quake Face Freezing Weather Conditions
description: Rescuers rushed to distribute blankets and tents to those displaced by the magnitude-7.1 quake that struck Tibetan villages near Nepal, toppling over 3,000 homes.
content: Rescuers working in subzero conditions and bracing winds searched the rubble on Wednesday after a strong quake in Tibet toppled thousands of houses in a remote area near the northern foothills of Mount Everest. Tens of thousands of residents were being transferred to safety while dozens were being treated for injuries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch Timothée Chalamet Perform in ‘A Complete Unknown’
description: The director James Mangold narrates a sequence from his biopic.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren and Catie Edmondson
title: Tax Cuts or the Border? Republicans Wrestle Over Priorities.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump has waffled on his preferences for how his party tackles his agenda, adding to the uncertainty for Republicans.
content: Republicans are preparing to cut taxes, slash spending and slow immigration in a broad agenda that will require unifying an unruly party behind dozens of complicated policy choices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: DGA Nominations: ‘Emilia Pérez’ and ‘The Brutalist’ In, ‘Wicked’ Out
description: Also snubbed was Coralie Fargeat of “The Substance” and other female filmmakers, though Payal Kapadia and Megan Park are up for best first feature.
content: Nominations for the Directors Guild of America’s feature-film award were announced on Wednesday, and though “Wicked” led the Screen Actors Guild nominations announced just hours before, that film’s director, Jon M. Chu, was nowhere to be found on this lineup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: As Fires Close Schools, Children’s Well Being Is a Concern
description: Young people are more vulnerable to air pollution and smoke inhalation, and can suffer trauma from the destruction of homes and schools.
content: As wildfires raged across Southern California on Wednesday, thousands of young people across the region faced the risk of physical and emotional distress caused by the disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton and Kate Kelly
title: A ‘Business-Friendly’ Lawyer’s Rise From Lobbyist to Attorney General Pick
description: Pam Bondi, whom President-elect Donald J. Trump intends to nominate as attorney general, received trips and donations funded by those seeking favors from her Florida office.
content: Halfway through the first Trump administration, Carnival Corporation, the world’s biggest cruise line, had a problem in Cuba that it wanted the president to fix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: With Stakes High, Lebanese Lawmakers to Try Again to Choose a President
description: Despite pressure by the United States and others to elect a president in order to receive financial support, a consensus candidate has yet to emerge who can clearly end Lebanon’s political gridlock.
content: Lebanon’s deeply divided Parliament is set Thursday to try to elect a new president, potentially ending a yearslong political vacuum and ushering in a degree of stability for a country reeling from its bloodiest war in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Canada’s Camera-Ready Politician
description: A magnet for cameras, Justin Trudeau was at the center of moments that defined Canada’s image over the last decade.
content: The image of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau receiving a vaccine against the coronavirus, like those of other world leaders, was meant to convey a reassuring public health message. It also put prim and buttoned-up politicians in the rare, if sometimes awkward, position of showing more skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Please Don’t Eat Your Christmas Tree, Belgium Urges the Public
description: The country’s food agency warned against using evergreens in food after the city of Ghent suggested an unusual form of recycling: spruce needle butter.
content: Go ahead and recycle your Christmas tree. But please, the Belgian authorities say, don’t try to eat it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer and Theodore Tae
title: A 15-Minute Full-Body Kettlebell Workout
description: This workout, which strengthens both your muscles and your heart, can be done at home or in the gym.
content: If you could only choose one piece of fitness equipment, it would be hard to beat the kettlebell. This strangely shaped object, with its flat-bottomed bell and easy-to-grip handle, is a versatile tool to train strength, balance and cardiovascular health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Who Is the Developer Behind Trump’s $20 Billion Data Center Pledge?
description: Hussain Sajwani, the founder and chairman of DAMAC Properties of Dubai, built the first Trump-branded golf course in the Middle East a decade ago.
content: When President-elect Donald J. Trump called Hussain Sajwani to the lectern at Mar-a-Lago on Tuesday to promise a $20 billion investment in the United States, it was a moment for the Dubai developer to savor. For more than a decade, his company, DAMAC Properties, has helped generate millions for the Trump Organization through a partnership in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Acknowledges He Might Not Have Been Able to Serve Four More Years
description: President Biden insisted that he still could have beaten Donald J. Trump had he stayed in the race, but could not say he would have been vital enough to be president until age 86.
content: President Biden acknowledged in a new interview released on Wednesday that he might not have had the vitality to serve another four years in office, even as he insisted that he could have won re-election had he stayed in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Marche
title: Justin Trudeau Was His Own Worst Enemy
description: He came to power with a new kind of politics — progressive and identity-based. In the end, it proved his undoing.
content: In the sunny beginnings of Justin Trudeau’s time in power, a journalist asked him why his cabinet was 50 percent female. Mr. Trudeau gave a now well-known response: “Because it’s 2015.” If you want to know why on Monday he announced his plan to resign as prime minister, the answer is just as simple: Because it’s 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: What’s Behind Meta’s MAGA Makeover?
description: Mark Zuckerberg is positioning his company for a second Trump term — and revealing the hollow identity at its core.
content: For years, Mark Zuckerberg tried to keep his social networks above the fray of partisan politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Maggie Haberman and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Trump Inauguration, Awash in Cash, Runs Out of Perks for Big Donors
description: The president-elect has raised more than $170 million for his swearing-in, an inaugural record, as wealthy Americans flock to curry favor with him and some give money even without the prospect of V.I.P. access.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural committee is no longer selling tickets for major donors to attend his swearing-in and accompanying private events in Washington, according to five people briefed on the conversations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: A Far-Right Government in Austria Would Be a Jolt, but Not Unexpected
description: The Freedom Party and its leader, Herbert Kickl, have steadily built support by demonizing immigrants, while entering Austria’s political mainstream.
content: The political party on the verge of leading Austria would take an already conservative country into a growing group of nations shifting to the far-right of European politics. It has flirted with Nazi slogans, cozied up to Russia and drawn warnings from Holocaust survivors’ groups. It campaigned on promises to deport immigrants and ban political forms of Islam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nostrant
title: Where California Residents Can Find Updates and Shelter
description: Here’s where people affected by the wildfires can find the latest information on emergency resources.
content: Three major wildfires are ravaging the Los Angeles area for a second day on Wednesday, after destroying more than 1,000 buildings, according to officials, and displacing tens of thousands of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Hostage Is Found Dead in Gaza Tunnel, Israel Says
description: The hostage, Youssef Ziyadne, an Arab Bedouin, was seized along with three grown children on Oct. 7, 2023. Two of them were released, but there is “serious concern” about the fate of the third.
content: The Israeli military said on Wednesday that it had discovered the body of a hostage taken from Israel on Oct. 7, 2023 in an underground tunnel in the area of Rafah in the Gaza Strip, along with evidence that raises questions about the state of another, related captive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Several Local Landmarks Are Destroyed in Southern California Wildfires
description: A high school used in many films, a synagogue and several well-known restaurants are among the structures that burned, while other local landmarks are endangered.
content: The wildfires that continued to burn through Southern California on Wednesday have gutted a number of local landmarks in some of the most affluent areas of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Brazil Is in Grave Danger. These 1,105 Pages Prove It.
description: There’s a dagger hanging over the country.
content: Two years ago, there was a coup attempt in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Biden Administration Moves to Halt Sept. 11 Plea Deal
description: Justice Department lawyers are defending the defense secretary’s decision to back out of the agreement that avoided a death penalty trial, moving the question from military to civilian courts.
content: The U.S. government asked a federal appeals court on Tuesday to stop Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the man accused of planning the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, from pleading guilty on Friday at the war court at Guantánamo Bay.The filing argued that, contrary to the findings of two lower military courts, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had the authority to retroactively withdraw the government from plea agreements that were submitted at the military court last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: U.K. Special Forces Allowed to ‘Get Away With Murder’ in Afghanistan, Inquiry Told
description: Evidence released by an official inquiry into alleged war crimes painted a disturbing picture of an elite fighting force with a culture of impunity.
content: British special forces soldiers used extreme methods against militants in Afghanistan, including covering a man with a pillow before shooting him with a pistol, as well as killing unarmed people, according to testimony released Wednesday by an inquiry into the actions of British troops during the war there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
title: In Death, Jean-Marie Le Pen of France Is Embraced by Far-Right Party He Once Led
description: For years, the far-right National Rally tried to distance itself from Mr. Le Pen’s racist and antisemitic remarks. But after his death Tuesday, it hailed him as a visionary.
content: For years, France’s main far-right party tried to distance itself from the long trail of inflammatory and derogatory comments made by Jean-Marie Le Pen, its founding president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Blaze Turns Pacific Palisades Into Evacuation Zone
description: Cars clogged scenic Sunset Boulevard and headed away from the Palisades, a seaside neighborhood on the west side of Los Angeles.
content: Against a towering backdrop of black smoke with an ominous orange glow, the stately homes and broad boulevards of the Pacific Palisades looked small and exposed on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Eaton Fire Erupts in Intensity Amid High Winds
description: The blaze more than doubled in size within hours. It is one of multiple wildfires raging out of control near Los Angeles.
content: The Eaton fire, burning out-of-control near Pasadena east of Los Angeles, was quickly increasing in size on Wednesday morning amid dangerous high winds, according to California fire officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Day 3: For Healthy Snacks You Actually Crave, Try a Sprinkle of ‘Flavor Dust’
description: Today’s challenge includes recipes you can try.
content: This is Day 3 of the 5-Day Healthier Eating Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: For the Love of Lemons
description: Lemony Greek chicken and spinach stew, broiled salmon with mustard and lemon, lemon-pepper tofu and lemon-almond butter cake are full of sour power.
content: I wrote an ode to anchovies on Monday and got a wave of great feedback. Thanks for all of your wonderful notes and suggestions — I’m thrilled to be surrounded by so many small-fish aficionados. (A-fish-ionados?) Give it up for the ’choves, as one passionate reader calls them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: The Republican Superstars Eager to Wish You Happy Birthday
description: Matt Gaetz, George Santos, Roger Stone — the celebrity-video app Cameo has become a key stop for embattled or notorious political figures.
content: “Hey, Luke,” former Representative George Santos says from what appears to be the passenger seat of a parked car. “I just wanted to stop by to wish you a super happy birthday.” His inflection rises over the last three words. “And a happy new year. Holy [expletive], you’re gonna be 23. And, Jesus, so young. And you’re studying for the LSAT, so I know you’re gonna crush it.” Santos raises his eyebrows and passes on regards from Luke’s brother, who wanted Santos to send these birthday wishes because “what better than an icon to icon?” He blows a kiss before telling Luke to “crush the LSAT” and every single goal after that. “The sky is the limit,” he says, and signs off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Meta will stop using third-party fact-checkers on Facebook, Threads and Instagram, a policy once instituted to curtail the spread of misinformation across the tech company’s social media platforms. Meta will instead rely on users to add notes to posts that may be false or misleading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John D. Leshy
title: Utah Wants the Supreme Court to Give It Land Owned by All Americans
description: Millions of acres could face largely unregulated exploitation.
content: No state in recent years has been more aggressive than Utah, home to some of the nation’s most magnificent landscapes, in trying to seize control of land owned by the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Why ‘Show Boat’ Is America’s Most Enduring, Unstable Musical
description: A revival called “Show/Boat: A River” joins a history of reimagining the musical that goes back nearly a century, to its first performances.
content: Few musicals have as much to say, and as much that could be said about them, as “Show Boat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Opening Your First Restaurant in New York? We Want to Hear From You.
description: We want to follow a budding restaurateur as they set up shop in New York and navigate the city’s dining scene.
content: New York City dining is back in a big way. Restaurants are opening in record numbers, many of them lavish, well-funded establishments with big-name chefs. So how does a first-time restaurateur make it in such a crowded, competitive field? I’d like to follow an owner (or owners) as they plan, build, staff and open a restaurant, navigating all the hurdles, from negotiating a lease to obtaining a liquor license to creating a menu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Russian Strike Kills 13 in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine
description: The attack, which also wounded dozens of people, came hours after Ukraine’s military attacked an oil depot deep inside Russia.
content: Russia bombed the city of Zaporizhzhia in southeastern Ukraine on Wednesday, officials said, killing at least 13 people and wounding dozens in a brazen daytime attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: California Wildfires Threaten Insurers Already Teetering From Climate Shocks
description: Companies started pulling back from the state as earlier fires made it harder to turn a profit. Experts warn the exodus could grow.
content: It’s too soon to know the financial cost of the wildfires burning around Los Angeles. But the toll on California’s troubled insurance market could be enormous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Consulate at Heart of Adams Case Got Special Treatment, Review Finds
description: The Turkish Consulate was the only building of its size allowed to open without a required fire safety certification, an investigation by the city comptroller found.
content: The Turkish Consulate at the center of the federal charges against Mayor Eric Adams was the only building of its size allowed to open without a required fire safety certification, according to an investigation the city comptroller released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: A Fashion Reporter Considers the Ways Trends Trickle Down
description: Jacob Gallagher, who covers men’s style for The Times, writes about teddy bear jeans, papal robes and all the fashion moments in between.
content: On a chilly day in December, Jacob Gallagher, a men’s fashion reporter for the Styles desk of The New York Times, is wearing a button-up shirt and black slacks, one of about a dozen pairs he owns. The look is put together, but casual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Sam Altman’s Younger Sister Files Lawsuit Claiming He Sexually Abused Her
description: OpenAI’s chief executive and founder denies the allegations, which are similar to claims his sister has long made online.
content: Ann Altman, the younger sister of OpenAI’s chief executive and founder, Sam Altman, filed a lawsuit in a Missouri federal court on Monday accusing him of sexually abusing her when she was a minor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Dripping Faucets and Seizing Greenland: Trump Is Back and Chaos Ensues
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s news conference at Mar-a-Lago was a reminder of what the next four years may have in store.
content: There was talk of the rising number of beached whales in Massachusetts, the victim, the president-elect said, of those windmills that have been erected off the coast. They “are driving the whales crazy, obviously.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Tan
title: AT&T to Credit Customers After Internet Outages
description: The announcement follows a year of high-profile internet blackouts that hit several companies.
content: AT&T announced on Wednesday that it would start crediting customers for internet outages and long wait times, the latest initiative in a yearslong effort to revamp the company’s customer service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Soumya Karlamangla
title: Barbara Lee, a Progressive Pillar of the House, Is Running for Oakland Mayor
description: The Bay Area politician, known for her antiwar position and breaking barriers in Congress, just left the House after more than two decades.
content: Former Representative Barbara Lee, a Bay Area progressive known for her lonely opposition to the war in Afghanistan after the Sept. 11 attacks and for her rise within the House’s Democratic leadership, on Wednesday joined the race for mayor of Oakland, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,300
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Jan. 9, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Legacy From Carter That Democrats Would Prefer to Escape
description: For decades, Republicans have reveled in invoking Jimmy Carter’s name to deride Democrats as weak — mockery that has influenced the way Democrats present themselves to voters.
content: Since his death, Jimmy Carter has been lauded for brokering the Camp David Accords and for his post-White House mission to help the poor and battle disease. But glossed over amid all the tributes is the burdensome legacy that Mr. Carter left for his Democratic Party: a presidency long caricatured as a symbol of ineffectiveness and weakness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Amy Pearl, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Rowan Niemisto and Dan Powell
title: Finding the Magic, Just in Time
description: Clare Cory was 59 years old and had been single almost her whole life. She thought her love story was over. Then everything changed.
content: When Clare Cory was a young girl, she dreamed of love. But by the time she turned 50, Clare hadn’t found it. Still, she took a look around and found she was happy and was looking forward to the future. Clare fell in love with life. She saw a flower bloom, watched sunlight sparkle on the water and held her cat on her lap. Her heart was full.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 8, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2025.
content: An article on Saturday about President Jimmy Carter’s treaties with Panama misstated the rank of Omar Torrijos Herrera when he seized power in Panama in 1968 in a military coup. He was a lieutenant colonel at the time, not a brigadier general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones and Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: The Worst Winds Are Easing in Southern California, but Fire Danger Will Remain
description: The gusty winds that helped spread multiple wildfires gradually subsided on Wednesday afternoon, but dry conditions mean less potent winds could still be dangerous. More strong winds are expected later Thursday.
content: The windy weather conditions that have fueled the furious spread of wildfires in Southern California finally started to ease on Wednesday afternoon. The worst winds may be over, but the fire danger remains, and another round of powerful winds is expected to pick up again on Thursday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French, Lydia Polgreen and Bret Stephens
title: ‘Trump Is at His Absolute Worst in a Crisis’: Three Columnists Imagine the World Ahead
description: What are the biggest challenges and opportunities facing Trump and his team in foreign policy and national security?
content: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists David French, Lydia Polgreen and Bret Stephens about the biggest risks and challenges facing America in the world today and the leadership of President Biden and President-elect Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Richard Fausset
title: Blinken and Top French Diplomat Criticize Trump’s Talk of Taking Greenland
description: In Paris, the two officials acknowledged potential strains on alliances with the return of Donald J. Trump to power, but said their countries would try to maintain strong ties.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his French counterpart, Jean-Noël Barrot, spoke on Wednesday in Paris of the challenges already posed to U.S. alliances by the imminent return of Donald J. Trump to the White House, and said they believed that an American takeover of Greenland was an impossible idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Was ‘Defeated Very Badly’ in Syria, a Top General Admits
description: For weeks, Iranian officials have downplayed the fall of their ally in Syria. But an important general has offered a remarkably candid view of the blow to Iran, and its military’s prospects.
content: Iran’s top-ranking general in Syria has contradicted the official line taken by Iran’s leaders on the sudden downfall of their ally Bashar al-Assad, saying in a remarkably candid speech last week that Iran had suffered a major defeat but would still try to operate in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Some of Los Angeles’s Most Expensive Real Estate Is Burning
description: In Pacific Palisades, the median sale price for a home was $3.3 million in December, according to Redfin.
content: Los Angeles is among the most densely populated cities in the United States, and its layout is compounding property losses. The city and surrounding towns also have some of the most expensive real estate in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The Perfect Housewarming Present for Trump’s Second Term
description: Trump may be inheriting ‘Morning in America’. Will Americans accept being happy?
content: Already, liberals are complaining that Donald Trump is returning to the White House on a golden parachute, just in time to benefit from a Democratic recovery. The former president owes his re-election in significant part to economic discontent, but as Kamala Harris surrogates tried unsuccessfully to emphasize through the fall, nearly all conventional indicators — inflation, unemployment, growth — have improved dramatically since the pandemic period.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Thousands Face Mandatory Evacuations Across Los Angeles Area
description: Three fires prompted fire officials to issue a swath of evacuation orders and warnings for some of the city’s most heavily residential areas.
content: Large residential areas across Los Angeles, including some of its most affluent ZIP codes in Malibu, were under mandatory evacuation orders on Wednesday as strong winds and dry conditions fueled the Palisades fire.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Syrians Rejoice in a Damascus Once Off Limits
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 7, 2025.
content: “We feel like seeing the country anew; we feel like tourists.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Prevail in Virginia Races, the First Elections Since Trump’s Win
description: The party held onto two key seats in Loudoun County that will allow them to maintain control of the state’s legislature.
content: Democrats on Tuesday held two key state legislative seats in Virginia, retaining their majorities in the General Assembly in the first special elections since President-elect Donald J. Trump won back the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Could the Oscars Be This Cool?
description: If the nominations that are unveiled next week include these contenders, it would be the best kind of surprise from an academy often known for missteps.
content: I sometimes feel like I’m making Oscar predictions from a defensive crouch, already anticipating what the academy might get wrong. Still, hope springs eternal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Where Do Your Spices Come From?
description: Burlap & Barrel, a spice company that sources directly from farms around the world, has become a secret ingredient used by celebrity chefs and home cooks alike.
content: In 2012, Ethan Frisch was working for a development organization in Afghanistan when he saw a vendor selling wild cumin at a local market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft
title: Narrow Hillside Roads Complicate Escape From Palisades Fire
description: Pacific Palisades feels like paradise on most days, but evacuating it in a disaster can be a real challenge.
content: In Pacific Palisades, homes are nestled into the hillside with breathtaking views, accessible via narrow roads that lead to just a handful of streets connecting to the Pacific Coast Highway. On Tuesday, these limited escape routes complicated the evacuation of tens of thousands of people from the rapidly growing Palisades fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Presidential Odd Couple: After a Tough Race, Carter and Ford Became Friends
description: Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford faced off in 1976 in a bitter campaign but later bonded as few presidents have — and made a pact to speak at each other’s funerals.
content: They did not think much of each other at first. They crisscrossed the country for months, warning voters that the other one should not be trusted with power. Their campaign was as bitter as any of the era and ended in one of the closest elections in modern times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Ed Van Put, Who Hooked Jimmy Carter on the Catskills, Dies at 88
description: A master fly-fisherman, author and conservationist, he guided the famous, including a former president, and the not-so-famous in the hunt for rainbow trout.
content: Thanks to Ed Van Put, Jimmy Carter and George Washington had something else in common aside from being Southern planters who ascended to the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Visiting Dissident Is Gunned Down in Bangkok
description: The killing of a former Cambodian politician stoked safety fears that Thailand is no refuge for those fleeing autocracy.
content: The killer was waiting by a noodle stand on Tuesday afternoon, on a busy street in Bangkok, with foreign backpackers milling around. When the bus traveling from the border with Cambodia pulled up, he strolled toward it, video footage released by the Thai police showed. Three shots rang out, like firecrackers, witnesses said. Then the assassin casually returned to the noodle stand, where his motorcycle was parked, and left the scene of the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Kevin Draper
title: Saudi Arabia, Already Pumping Money Into Boxing, May Start League With TKO
description: A company owned by the country’s sovereign wealth fund is poised to team up with TKO, which owns Ultimate Fighting Championship, the kingdom’s latest foray into pro sports.
content: In the days after Donald J. Trump was re-elected president, one of his most high-profile stops was at an Ultimate Fighting Championship event at Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Former MoviePass Executive Pleads Guilty to Fraud Over ‘Unlimited’ Plan
description: Prosecutors said that Theodore Farnsworth, who ran the parent company of MoviePass, had misled investors about its popular subscription plan.
content: Theodore Farnsworth, the former chief executive of the parent company of MoviePass, pleaded guilty to securities fraud on Tuesday after federal prosecutors said he had misled investors about the company’s “unlimited” subscription plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Perry the Donkey, Model for ‘Shrek,’ Dies at 30
description: As Perry’s health declined, fans rallied behind the animal and his companions living in a Bay Area park.
content: Perry, a miniature donkey whose handlers said he was used by DreamWorks animators as a model for the chatty “Shrek” character named Donkey, died last week at the age of 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek, Abu Bakr Bashir and Lara Jakes
title: Trump’s Threat About Hostages Frustrates Gazans: ‘It Is Already Hell’
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump said “all hell will break out in the Middle East” if hostages captured in the Hamas-led attacks were not freed before he takes office.
content: For more than a year, almost two million Palestinians living in Gaza have been homeless, facing severe food and medical shortages and under enduring threat of Israeli airstrikes. Nearly 46,000 Gazans have been killed, local health officials said on Wednesday, in a landscape largely reduced to rubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Director of Netflix’s ‘Jerry Springer Show’ Documentary Offers 5 Takeaways
description: Luke Sewell spoke about the complex legacy of the notorious talk show, which both coarsened American culture and affirmed the values of free speech.
content: Ask people why American culture is going down the tubes, and the culprits might be partisanship, declining trust in institutions, empty calorie entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A Light, Bright Feast for After the Holidays
description: Resolutions don’t have to be synonymous with restraint, as this tangy beet salad, stunning herbed rice and easy apple tart from David Tanis show.
content: In January after all the holiday gluttony (or even slightly sooner), I always want to pivot to something lighter. I often look to the Eastern Mediterranean for inspiration, counting on lots of bright flavors featuring spices, fresh herbs, lemon and olive oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: Pluto May Have Captured Its Biggest Moon After an Ancient Dance and Kiss
description: Charon is large in size relative to Pluto, and is locked in a tight orbit with the dwarf planet. A new simulation suggests how it ended up there.
content: Some 4.5 billion years ago, the dwarf planet Pluto was suddenly joined by a companion. For a very brief period — perhaps only hours — they danced as if arm in arm before gently separating, a grand do-si-do that resulted in Pluto and its quintet of moons orbiting the sun together today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Sampson
title: Can Trump Really Rename the Gulf of Mexico the ‘Gulf of America’?
description: Presidential naming powers usually stop at the water’s edge.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump said Tuesday that he planned to change the name of the Gulf of Mexico to the “Gulf of America,” one of several foreign policy proposals that left world leaders reeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: actuarial
description: This word has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word actuarial has appeared in 13 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 2 in the guest essay “The Surprising Allure of Ignorance” by Mark Lilla:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Raging Fires in Los Angeles Raze Homes and Force Evacuations
description: Multiple fires in the area were burning largely unchecked on Thursday, killing at least five people.
content: Follow continuing coverage of the wildfires in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Wildfires Intensify Pivotal Moment for Insurance Industry
description: California’s vulnerable homeowners insurance industry faces a test as fires rage across Los Angeles.
content: With over 13,000 homes at risk, the losses from the Los Angeles wildfires could approach $10 billion, according to preliminary estimates by J.P. Morgan. The financial devastation threatens to upend an insurance market that is already under profound financial strain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: We Are Not Prepared for Fires Like This
description: A decade ago, this kind of disaster seemed unthinkably rare.
content: Tuesday night, a historic wind event swept through Southern California, spreading horrifying fires that torched a dense urban patchwork of homes, institutions and businesses. The multiple fires in greater Los Angeles have produced only two deaths so far, somewhat mercifully. But the windstorm is expected to continue, and already much of Pacific Palisades has burned to an unrecognizable gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan
title: ‘Breaking Bad’ House Listed for $3.995 Million
description: The price of the modest four-bedroom in Albuquerque reflects the home’s pop cultural significance, a listing agent said.
content: The house that doubled as Walter White’s on the TV show “Breaking Bad” has hit the market — at the lofty price of nearly $4 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Devlin Barrett
title: Trump’s Lawyers Have Assailed Jack Smith. They Could Soon Have Power to Go After Him.
description: The president-elect’s defense lawyers accused the special counsel of unethical and improper behavior in his prosecutions of their client. They could be in senior Justice Department roles within weeks.
content: In many ways, the letter that President-elect Donald J. Trump’s criminal defense lawyers sent to the Justice Department this week was a display of legal and political bombast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Animal Shelters Are Stretched Thin With Displaced Pets
description: Some owners fled with their pets, but a network of facilities in the Los Angeles area is straining to care for the hundreds of animals left behind.
content: Nicole Montanez called four hotels on Tuesday before finding a room where she could safely evacuate with her son and her 4-year-old Havanese, Diego. The dog coughed throughout the 75-minute car ride from Pacific Palisades to Marina del Rey, where the family was taking shelter from the wildfires searing through Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Surveyor’s Measure
description: Laura Dershewitz’s puzzle nets positive.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: A Low-Tech Way to Save Babies’ Lives
description: Researchers say hundreds of thousands of babies’ lives could be saved each year in developing countries with exclusive breastfeeding.
content: Every year I choose a university student to accompany me on my win-a-trip journey, which is meant to highlight issues that deserve more attention. My latest winner was Trisha Mukherjee, a recent Columbia graduate and a budding journalist — and with that, I’m handing the rest of the column to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Mark Zuckerberg and the Art of Reading the Room
description: Meta’s plan to end its fact-checking program shows how business leaders are shifting their priorities to adapt to another Trump administration.
content: Meta’s bombshell announcement on Tuesday that it would end its fact-checking program was widely read as a major shift in policy meant to please President-elect Donald Trump and other conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Israeli Strike in West Bank Kills 3, Including Children
description: Violence has escalated in the occupied territory over the last year and a half, as Israel conducts raids targeting armed fighters with Hamas and Palestinian Islamic Jihad.
content: An Israeli drone strike killed three cousins, including two children, in the West Bank on Wednesday, according to Palestinian officials and a family member, as growing violence threatens to further destabilize the Israeli-occupied territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Maya Tekeli
title: ‘Make Greenland Great Again’? No Thank You, Greenlanders Say.
description: After Donald Trump suggested he might take over Greenland by force, the consensus among the island’s population appears to be bewilderment and anxiety.
content: Christian Ulloriaq Jeppesen remembers how this all started.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Los Angeles Area Braces for Strong Winds That Will Fan Flames
description: Officials warned that winds would strengthen overnight, creating conditions for the Palisades blaze to grow and for others to start.
content: Follow continuing coverage of the wildfires in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Audra Melton
title: It Was Dark, Freezing and 4 a.m. Still, They Came to See Jimmy Carter.
description: It was a once-in-a-lifetime chance to pay their respects to a president. They were not going to miss it, even if meant waking up in the middle of the night.
content: The early morning sky was a pool of ink, and the air was violently cold, at least by the standards of a Southerner by way of Nigeria. Still, Cornelius Ani pulled himself out of bed on Tuesday, bundled up and drove in 30 miles from the Atlanta suburbs. He had to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: U.A.W. Seeks Union Election at Ford Battery Joint Venture in Kentucky
description: The United Automobile Workers union asked a federal labor regulator to conduct an election at a factory Ford jointly owns with a South Korean battery company.
content: The United Automobile Workers union is seeking approval from federal labor regulators for a union election among workers at a Ford Motor battery plant in Kentucky, providing an important test of organized labor’s strength after the election of Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Artists Tried to Activate Voters With Billboard Art. Did It Work?
description: For Freedoms’ billboards could surprise, comfort or confuse. Now the group is asking, Where do we go from here?
content: On Nov. 6, the day after the presidential election, the artist Hank Willis Thomas was at his studio in Brooklyn. His production assistants were poring over tables strewed with blobby red white and blue silk-screen prints of the words “Fragile/ Democracy / Handle With Care” in capital letters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Joe Rennison
title: More Companies Are Betting on Bitcoin
description: It is a sharp pivot away from the cautious approach of the traditional corporate treasury, normally charged with safeguarding cash rather than chasing higher returns.
content: A couple of weeks after the presidential election, Joe Davy, chief executive of the marketing firm Banzai, sent an email to the company’s board of directors: He wanted Banzai to start buying Bitcoin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Punk and Emo Fossils Are a Hot Topic in Paleontology
description: It’s not causing panic! in the fossil record, but a 430-million-year-old mollusk discovery in Britain is a source of excitement for some scientists.
content: Mark Sutton, an Imperial College London paleontologist, is not a punk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Zach Levitt, Joey K. Lee, Bea Malsky, Lazaro Gamio, John Keefe, Agnes Chang and Pablo Robles
title: Maps: Tracking the Los Angeles Wildfires
description: Fires driven by fierce winds scorched parts of the Los Angeles area, destroying homes and filling the sky with smoke.
content: Fires driven by fierce winds scorched parts of the Los Angeles area, destroying homes and filling the sky with smoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Wildfire Burns Quickly in Southern California
description: Fierce winds whipped up flames that destroyed homes in Los Angeles and forced the evacuation of residents in areas including Santa Monica and the Pacific Palisades.
content: Fierce winds whipped up flames that destroyed homes in Los Angeles and forced the evacuation of residents in areas including Santa Monica and the Pacific Palisades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Leventhal
title: Carter’s Coffin Transferred to Washington
description: Former President Jimmy Carter’s body was moved on Tuesday from his home state of Georgia to Washington, where it will lie in state in the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol until Thursday.
content: Former President Jimmy Carter’s body was moved on Tuesday from his home state of Georgia to Washington, where it will lie in state in the Rotunda of the U.S. Capitol until Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Mexico’s President Jokes That U.S. Should Be Called Mexican America
description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico sarcastically suggested that the United States be renamed Mexican America in response to President-elect Trump’s proposal to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America.
content: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico sarcastically suggested that the United States be renamed Mexican America in response to President-elect Trump’s proposal to rename the Gulf of Mexico to the Gulf of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: ‘A Complete Unknown’ | Anatomy of a Scene
description: James Mangold narrates a sequence from his film, starring Timothée Chalamet.
content: James Mangold narrates a sequence from his film, starring Timothée Chalamet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Mourners Pay Their Respects to Former President Jimmy Carter
description: Visitors said their final goodbyes to Jimmy Carter, lying in state at the Capitol, and reflected on what the former president meant to them.
content: Visitors said their final goodbyes to Jimmy Carter, lying in state at the Capitol, and reflected on what the former president meant to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li
title: Multiple Wildfires Rage Around Los Angeles
description: The fires have consumed thousands of acres and have displaced more than 100,000 people.
content: The fires have consumed thousands of acres and have displaced more than 100,000 people.
source.name: The New York Times
